Name: Known molecule quantification
Description: Converts peak areas into absolute concentrations for molecules that have an authentic standard run alongside the samples.

Parameters.Name: Standard sheet source
Parameters.Description: Where should the standards sheet be read from? Must contain Compound_Name (matching the Name column in the Compounds table), Column (HILIC, RP, CYANO, or C18), z (aka charge, mostly -1 or +1), and Concentration_uM (standard conc. in micromolar). Sources can be a local file, a full URL, or a commit in the Ingalls Standards Github.

Parameters.Name: Column type
Parameters.Description: Chromatography column used for this dataset.

Parameters.Name: Volume filtered (L)
Parameters.Description: The volume of sample initially filtered, in liters. Used to calculate the degree to which the samples have been concentrated.

Parameters.Name: Reconstitution volume (L)
Parameters.Description: The volume of solvent (in liters) into which samples were reconstituted after dry-down. Used to calculate the degree to which the samples have been concentrated.

Parameters.Name: Dilution applied
Parameters.Description: What degree of dilution was applied during sampling? Sometimes samples can be too concentrated to behave well on the column. The default, 1, means no dilution was performed. A value of 2 would indicate that the samples were diluted 1:1 with water, a value of 4 would indicate 2:1 with water. I think.

Parameters.Name: Standard file regex
Parameters.Description: How should the authentic standards be identified? In the Ingalls Lab, we include _Std_ in file names of the single-point standard curve so we can pass the '_Std_' regular expression to str_detect to identify them.

Parameters.Name: Matrix regex
Parameters.Description: How should the standards in a matrix be distinguished from the standards in water that are typically run alongside? Provide a regular expression here that will return True when passed to str_detect with the file names.
